subjectDescription: Discover a full suite of online business courses that will allow you to make better business decisions and succeed in today's competitive business world. Our courses provide a rich learning experience that will allow you to develop critical business skills in areas such as business... Read more...
title: Basics of Finance and Accounting
headline: Learn how to organise and manage your accounting and financial records properly in this free online bookkeeping course.
description: This bookkeeping course covers essential accounting and finance principles in a practical and accessible way. We explain key accounting concepts and frameworks like accrual, conservatism, consistency, materiality and so on. We also discuss the difference between ‘accounting’ and ‘bookkeeping’ and provide the best inventory management practices before comparing the advantages of journals and ledgers. Sign up to take control of your finances.

courseDescription:
Finance and accounting jobs are among the most in-demand worldwide. They are needed in any type of company setting, from small businesses to large corporations. Those working in finance must be up to the task and function at their best to succeed in this fast-paced and fast-growing industry. This online course guides you through the basics and covers critical finance and accounting concepts. We provide you with an overview of bookkeeping and accounting while noting their differences and outlining the objectives and cycle of accounting.

The course then explores various accounting concepts and highlights the distinctions between cash and accrual accounting. We also lay out the conceptual framework of financial accounting and the fundamental accounting equation. We then explore the basics of bookkeeping such as the debits and credits rules and why appropriate debiting and crediting keep financial accounts balanced. The course also goes over some best practices for inventory management and provides strategies that make effective use of inventory management software.

We also study accounts payable and receivable in detail, the advantages of a journal and the distinction between journals and ledgers. We explain how to implement sales discounts, returns and business allowances. Lastly, we define key accounting terms like ‘financial condition’, ‘business valuation’ and ‘cash management’. This course benefits anyone interested in a career in finance or accounting or who simply want to understand their business to improve their decision-making. You can also learn how to monitor and manage the finances of a small business or make better decisions with your personal finances.

Start Course Now
certificateDetail:
All Alison courses are free to enrol study and complete. To successfully complete this certificate course and become an Alison Graduate, you need to achieve 80% or higher in each course assessment. Once you have completed this certificate course, you have the option to acquire an official Diploma, which is a great way to share your achievement with the world.

Your Alison certificate is:
  • Ideal for sharing with potential employers
  • Include it in your CV, professional social media profiles and job applications.
  • An indication of your commitment to continuously learn, upskill & achieve high results.
  • An incentive for you to continue empowering yourself through lifelong learning.
Alison offers 3 types of Diplomas for completed Diploma courses:
  • Digital certificate: a downloadable certificate in PDF format immediately available to you when you complete your purchase.
  • certificate: a physical version of your officially branded and security-marked certificate, posted to you with FREE shipping.
  • Framed certificate: a physical version of your officially branded and security marked certificate in a stylish frame, posted to you with FREE shipping.
Start Course Now

All certificate are available to purchase through the Alison Shop. For more information on purchasing Alison certificate, please visit our FAQs. If you decide not to purchase your Alison certificate, you can still demonstrate your achievement by sharing your Learner Record or Learner Achievement Verification, both of which are accessible from your Dashboard. For more details on our certificate pricing, please visit our Pricing Page

modules.name: Module
modules.description: This module will provide you with an overview of bookkeeping and accounting. You will also learn crucial accounting concepts and frameworks as well as the fundamental accounting equation. Also, you will study the best practices for inventory management, the differences between the journal and ledgers and some essential accounting terminologies.
topics: Accounting and Finance Fundamentals - Learning Outcomes
Accounting and Finance Fundamentals - Lesson Summary

modules.name: Module
topics: Basics of Finance and Accounting - Course Assessment

slides:
• Learning Outcomes

  • Having completed this module, you will be able to:
    • Identify the differences between bookkeeping and accounting
    • Discuss the conceptual framework of financial accounting
    • Explain how to input transactions into accounting records in simple stages
    • Recall the best practices for inventory management 
    • Summarize ways to write a sales diary to keep track of transactions

  • Tracking Purchases

  • Introduction to the Module
  • Your company must have something to sell in terms of generating money. You must deal with costs directly connected to the items or services you sell, whether you sell products or provide services. This module scratches the surface of inventory tracking and budgetary control. The procedure for paying invoices is outlined in Keeping Business Supply.
  • Topics to be covered in the lesson

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

    • · Keeping Track of Inventory
    • Accounts Payable
    • Accounts Receivable
    • The Journal
    • Advantages of Journal
    • Sub-Division of Journal
    • The General Ledger
    • Ruling of Ledger Account
    • Sub-division of Ledger
    • Distinction between Journal and Ledger
    • Cash Management
    • Summary

  • Tracking Purchases

  • Introduction to the Module
  • Your company must have something to sell in terms of generating money. You must deal with costs directly connected to the items or services you sell, whether you sell products or provide services. This module scratches the surface of inventory tracking and budgetary control. The procedure for paying invoices is outlined in Keeping Business Supply.

  • General Ledgers

  • A general ledger is a book or file used by bookkeepers to keep track of all pertinent accounts. Assets, liabilities, owner's capital, income, and costs are all tracked in the general ledger.
  • Transactions that appear in journals initially are then uploaded to general ledger accounts. Then, before appearing on a company's official financial statements, account balances are calculated and moved from the main ledger to a trial balance. Each accounting item is represented by a T-shaped table with two columns. The account title is usually written at the top of the "T," and debit and credit entries are recorded on the left and right sides, respectively. Additional columns for details such as transaction description, date, and serial number appear on occasion in the general ledger.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • Special Considerations
  • Most businesses now utilize accounting software to record transactions in general ledgers and journals, greatly simplifying these routine record-keeping tasks. In reality, most accounting software today maintains a single repository where businesses may concurrently store both ledger and journal entries. Because of technological advancements, recording transactions is easier and less time-consuming, and you don't have to keep track of each book of accounts separately. These repositories may be unknown to the individual inputting data in any module of your company's accounting or bookkeeping software. To enter a transaction in a ledger or journal, the data entry person in many of these software systems merely has to click a drop-down option.

The account title is usually written at the top of the "T," and debit and credit entries are recorded on the left and right sides, respectively. To enter a transaction in a ledger or journal, the data entry person in many of these software systems merely has to click a drop-down option.

  • Presenting Financial Condition & Business Valuation

  • Introduction to the Topic
  • In this chapter, Financial Condition is examined comprehensively, which introduces fundamental accounting terms. It clearly explains the assets that are utilized in balance sheets. Additionally, you will learn how to evaluate assets using alternative methodologies and how to calculate a business valuation. This chapter also looks at the many applications of valuations and the discipline of valuations as a profession.
  • Topics to be covered in this lesson
    • Define Financial Condition and its Types
    • Clarifying the Values of Assets in Balance Sheets
    • Introducing Business Valuation
    • Comparing Business Valuation Methods

  • Lesson Summary

  • The key points from this module are:
  • Bookkeeping is concerned with the recordkeeping parts of accounting, and it involves documenting all of the particular information pertaining to a business's transactions and operations.
  • Accountants issue orders, while bookkeeps carry them out.
  • Stakeholders are persons who are interested in a company's success or failure. Examples include stockholders, creditors and regulators. 
  • The fundamental accounting equation helps explain the concept that all transactions must balance.
  • Assets = Liabilities + Owners' equity
  • Accounting Concepts are the fundamental principles, assumptions, and circumstances that create the limits and restrictions that accounting must work within.
  • An accounting framework is a collection of established guidelines for measuring, recognizing, presenting, and disclosing information in a company's financial statements.
  • Cash-basis accounting and accrual accounting are the two most used accounting procedures. The moment at which you record revenue and costs in your records is the main distinction between these two accounting procedures.

  • Accountants issue orders, while bookkeeps carry them out.
  • Stakeholders are persons who are interested in a company's success or failure. Examples include stockholders, creditors and regulators. 
  • The fundamental accounting equation helps explain the concept that all transactions must balance.
  • Assets = Liabilities + Owners' equity
  • Accounting Concepts are the fundamental principles, assumptions, and circumstances that create the limits and restrictions that accounting must work within.
  • An accounting framework is a collection of established guidelines for measuring, recognizing, presenting, and disclosing information in a company's financial statements.
  • Cash-basis accounting and accrual accounting are the two most used accounting procedures. The moment at which you record revenue and costs in your records is the main distinction between these two accounting procedures.

  • Accounting Concepts are the fundamental principles, assumptions, and circumstances that create the limits and restrictions that accounting must work within.
  • An accounting framework is a collection of established guidelines for measuring, recognizing, presenting, and disclosing information in a company's financial statements.
